WRITING.TITLE: How much should we emphasize gender roles?
WRITING.TEXT:
I've been wondering, with all of this hither and yon about transgender, genderqueer, agender, etc. etc. if we had any hard and fast rules about the way we deal with each sex and how they ought to present themselves. I know someone, for example, who has been struggling with her femininity since many traditionally feminine things don't resonate with her. She doesn't like pink, enjoys wearing shirts and ties, typically prefers pants to dresses, etc. I'm pretty sure that she doesn't think of herself as trans, since she does like some stereotypically girly things like makeup, pretty clothes, and some dresses (like Victorian style), and has never indicated any belief that she's actually a male, but more that she has trouble seeing herself as wholly female. She goes back and forth with what she likes depending on her mood. I basically told her that none of that stuff has any impact on whether she's male or female, but rather just societally imposed norms that may statistically be more likely to be associated with one sex. Whether she likes typical girl things or typical boy things doesn't affect that she's a girl.
What I'm wondering is whether we have a clear delineation between essential and accidental qualities of males and females. I told her that it only really matters for issues having to do with reproduction and the family. For example, sex, marriage, and a child having a mother and a father. It seems like that's what's essential, and other parts are accidental which could change based on the individual. I'm hoping I'm giving her the right advice. She also is attracted to both sexes, which I think muddies the gender waters a bit for her. She accepts the Church's teachings on sex and marriage for now, but it seems very tenuous and mostly based on not wanting to abandon the Church. She also doesn't think she'll ever want children. All that being said, she's still very young at only 16, so she's still got a lot about herself to figure out. She has some body image issues to work out as well, including battling anorexia.
I'm just wondering how to best encourage her with embracing her femininity while still staying true to herself and the wonderful person that God made her. Is there an optimal balance bewteen essential qualities of the sexes and societal norms that we should try to maintain? Does anyone have any advice for this type of case?

The worst (and by that I mean most horrifying, not most logically unsound) arguments I see are the ones that either acknowledge the fetus is a human or dismiss it as irrelevant. These usually revolve around the principle of bodily autonomy. While a person does have the right to bodily autonomy, up to a certain point, this right can be superseded by something greater. A person could be quarantined against their will, for example, if they had a deadly contagious disease, even though they are blameless. I also notice that the typical person who uses bodily autonomy as an argument for access to abortion also believes in mandatory vaccinations.
If preserving your bodily autonomy requires you to kill an innocent human being, you do not have that right. Murder (in the moral sense not the useless legal one) is always impermissible under any and all circumstances. Not to preserve your bodily autonomy, not to preserve your life, not to preserve the world from destruction. Evil can never be done to achieve a good end.
This line of argument also assumes that a mother owes nothing more to her child than any random person off the street. Given how the human organism reproduces and gestates, a fetus absolutely has the right to its mother's womb and nutrients for the duration of the pregnancy. People like to talk about rights and not responsibilities. A mother has the responsibility to care for her child (a father also has a responsibility to care for the mother and unborn child during the pregnancy, and subsequently after the birth, but that's not what's being discussed). Whether or not the mother intended on conceiving, either through rape or a misunderstanding on the purpose of sex, they still owe their child care. Luckily we live in a world where people will step in after birth to fill this void if the parents are unable to provide it, but the natural course is for parents to provide it.
A child has a right to their natural mother and father, and this should only be superseded in extreme circumstances, and never at the expense of the child's life. As of now, only the natural mother can provide a suitable environment for gestation, so they are morally required to do so. Not all duties and obligations are ones we obtain voluntarily. Sometimes they are thrust upon us unbidden, but we are no less bound to them. Unfortunately we live in a society that values personal freedom and choice above virtue, and people aren't willing to make universally binding moral declarations.

I think the other responders so far aren't directly addressing OP's question. Clearly Mary did have a choice to assent to God's will or to resist it (unless you're a Calvinist), but what OP is asking is whether or not she could have prevented the Incarnation if she had denied God's will instead of accepting it. Or, to put it a more crude way, would God have forcibly impregnated Mary with Jesus if she did not want Him to?
I think that this is an interesting question, since by resisting God's will she would have no longer been without sin, and thus an unsuitable vessel for the Incarnation. At the same time, God's perfect foreknowledge means that He knew that she would be perpetually sinless and would thus assent. So yes, if Mary had said no, the Incarnation would not have happened, but if she were going to say no then God wouldn't have asked.

They didn't have a word for gay marriage in the same way that they didn't have a word for four-sided triangles, in that they both describe something that doesn't exist. Marriage wasn't about "two people who wuv each other vewwy much and want to have a party to show everyone", but rather a real ontological relationship between a man and a woman for the purpose of having and raising children. Being "in love" could have been part of the package, but it was by no means a necessity.
There are also several parts of the Old Testament where the debauchery of nations is expressed by how they exchange natural passions for unnatural ones, and then go on to say that the men were having relations with men and the women with women. This sort of behavior is used to describe when a nation fell away from God and followed their own appetites. Paul was likely specifically calling out instances like male temple prostitutes, since that was what was prevalent in his era, but the Jews already knew that sex outside of a marriage was wrong and didn't need to be told. It wasn't part of the new revelation of Christ, but something assumed so blatantly obvious that it didn't need restating.
So whether they had a word for a gay person, I don't know, because it's not important. What is important is the behavior. And extra-marital sexual activity has always been condemned. Pretending two men or two women are married doesn't make it real, and doesn't change the sinfulness of the acts.
